questiontext.text:
A child stands 2.3m from the axis of a rotating merry-go-round. The coefficient of friction between her shoes and the platform is 1.11.

What is the maximum angular velocity, $$\omega$$, of the merry-go-round if she is not to start slipping outwards?




Assume a value of $$g$$ = -9.8m/s2 for the purposes of this question.


$$\omega\$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=2.2:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s.

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
The frictional force, $$F_f$$, experienced preventing the child from slipping outwards can be expressed as:

$$F_f=\mu .R=\mu .M.g$$

Where $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of friction as given above, $$R$$ is the reaction force between her shoes and the platform, $$M$$ is the child's mass, and $$g$$ is the gravitational constant, as given above.


The centripetal force, $$F_c$$, experienced by the child can be expressed as:

$$F_c=M.a_c=M.r.\omega ^2$$

Where $$r$$ is the distance between the child and the centre of the merry-go-round, and $$a_c$$ is the centripetal acceleration.


At maximum velocity whilst the child is not slipping outwards, these two forces will be balanced. Therefore, equating and simplifying these two expressions gives:

$$\mu .g=r.\omega ^2$$

Therefore:

$$\omega =\sqrt{\frac{\mu .g}{r}}=2.2$$ rad/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from 'http://minerva.union.edu/labrakes/Phy110_E3_Solution_F11.pdf'

hint.text:
HINT

Develop expressions for both the frictional force and the centripetal force experienced by the child.

Remember that these will be balanced, when $$\omega$$ is at a maximum whilst the child is not slipping outwards.

A child stands 1.8m from the axis of a rotating merry-go-round. The coefficient of friction between her shoes and the platform is 1.12.

What is the maximum angular velocity, $$\omega$$, of the merry-go-round if she is not to start slipping outwards?




Assume a value of $$g$$ = -9.8m/s2 for the purposes of this question.


$$\omega\$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=2.5:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s.

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #17).

generalfeedback.text:
The frictional force, $$F_f$$, experienced preventing the child from slipping outwards can be expressed as:

$$F_f=\mu .R=\mu .M.g$$

Where $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of friction as given above, $$R$$ is the reaction force between her shoes and the platform, $$M$$ is the child's mass, and $$g$$ is the gravitational constant, as given above.


The centripetal force, $$F_c$$, experienced by the child can be expressed as:

$$F_c=M.a_c=M.r.\omega ^2$$

Where $$r$$ is the distance between the child and the centre of the merry-go-round, and $$a_c$$ is the centripetal acceleration.


At maximum velocity whilst the child is not slipping outwards, these two forces will be balanced. Therefore, equating and simplifying these two expressions gives:

$$\mu .g=r.\omega ^2$$

Therefore:

$$\omega =\sqrt{\frac{\mu .g}{r}}=2.5$$ rad/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
A child stands 1.8m from the axis of a rotating merry-go-round. The coefficient of friction between her shoes and the platform is 1.49.

What is the maximum angular velocity, $$\omega$$, of the merry-go-round if she is not to start slipping outwards?




Assume a value of $$g$$ = -9.8m/s2 for the purposes of this question.


$$\omega\$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=2.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s.

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #33).

generalfeedback.text:
The frictional force, $$F_f$$, experienced preventing the child from slipping outwards can be expressed as:

$$F_f=\mu .R=\mu .M.g$$

Where $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of friction as given above, $$R$$ is the reaction force between her shoes and the platform, $$M$$ is the child's mass, and $$g$$ is the gravitational constant, as given above.


The centripetal force, $$F_c$$, experienced by the child can be expressed as:

$$F_c=M.a_c=M.r.\omega ^2$$

Where $$r$$ is the distance between the child and the centre of the merry-go-round, and $$a_c$$ is the centripetal acceleration.


At maximum velocity whilst the child is not slipping outwards, these two forces will be balanced. Therefore, equating and simplifying these two expressions gives:

$$\mu .g=r.\omega ^2$$

Therefore:

$$\omega =\sqrt{\frac{\mu .g}{r}}=2.8$$ rad/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
A child stands 2.6m from the axis of a rotating merry-go-round. The coefficient of friction between her shoes and the platform is 1.2.

What is the maximum angular velocity, $$\omega$$, of the merry-go-round if she is not to start slipping outwards?




Assume a value of $$g$$ = -9.8m/s2 for the purposes of this question.


$$\omega\$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=2.1:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s.

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #49).

generalfeedback.text:
The frictional force, $$F_f$$, experienced preventing the child from slipping outwards can be expressed as:

$$F_f=\mu .R=\mu .M.g$$

Where $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of friction as given above, $$R$$ is the reaction force between her shoes and the platform, $$M$$ is the child's mass, and $$g$$ is the gravitational constant, as given above.


The centripetal force, $$F_c$$, experienced by the child can be expressed as:

$$F_c=M.a_c=M.r.\omega ^2$$

Where $$r$$ is the distance between the child and the centre of the merry-go-round, and $$a_c$$ is the centripetal acceleration.


At maximum velocity whilst the child is not slipping outwards, these two forces will be balanced. Therefore, equating and simplifying these two expressions gives:

$$\mu .g=r.\omega ^2$$

Therefore:

$$\omega =\sqrt{\frac{\mu .g}{r}}=2.1$$ rad/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
A child stands 1.7m from the axis of a rotating merry-go-round. The coefficient of friction between her shoes and the platform is 0.71.

What is the maximum angular velocity, $$\omega$$, of the merry-go-round if she is not to start slipping outwards?




Assume a value of $$g$$ = -9.8m/s2 for the purposes of this question.


$$\omega\$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=2:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s.

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #65).

generalfeedback.text:
The frictional force, $$F_f$$, experienced preventing the child from slipping outwards can be expressed as:

$$F_f=\mu .R=\mu .M.g$$

Where $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of friction as given above, $$R$$ is the reaction force between her shoes and the platform, $$M$$ is the child's mass, and $$g$$ is the gravitational constant, as given above.


The centripetal force, $$F_c$$, experienced by the child can be expressed as:

$$F_c=M.a_c=M.r.\omega ^2$$

Where $$r$$ is the distance between the child and the centre of the merry-go-round, and $$a_c$$ is the centripetal acceleration.


At maximum velocity whilst the child is not slipping outwards, these two forces will be balanced. Therefore, equating and simplifying these two expressions gives:

$$\mu .g=r.\omega ^2$$

Therefore:

$$\omega =\sqrt{\frac{\mu .g}{r}}=2$$ rad/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
A child stands 2.1m from the axis of a rotating merry-go-round. The coefficient of friction between her shoes and the platform is 0.83.

What is the maximum angular velocity, $$\omega$$, of the merry-go-round if she is not to start slipping outwards?




Assume a value of $$g$$ = -9.8m/s2 for the purposes of this question.


$$\omega\$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=2:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s.

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #81).

generalfeedback.text:
The frictional force, $$F_f$$, experienced preventing the child from slipping outwards can be expressed as:

$$F_f=\mu .R=\mu .M.g$$

Where $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of friction as given above, $$R$$ is the reaction force between her shoes and the platform, $$M$$ is the child's mass, and $$g$$ is the gravitational constant, as given above.


The centripetal force, $$F_c$$, experienced by the child can be expressed as:

$$F_c=M.a_c=M.r.\omega ^2$$

Where $$r$$ is the distance between the child and the centre of the merry-go-round, and $$a_c$$ is the centripetal acceleration.


At maximum velocity whilst the child is not slipping outwards, these two forces will be balanced. Therefore, equating and simplifying these two expressions gives:

$$\mu .g=r.\omega ^2$$

Therefore:

$$\omega =\sqrt{\frac{\mu .g}{r}}=2$$ rad/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Develop expressions for both the frictional force and the centripetal force experienced by the child.

Remember that these will be balanced, when $$\omega$$ is at a maximum whilst the child is not slipping outwards.

questiontext.text:
A child stands 1.2m from the axis of a rotating merry-go-round. The coefficient of friction between her shoes and the platform is 1.09.

What is the maximum angular velocity, $$\omega$$, of the merry-go-round if she is not to start slipping outwards?




Assume a value of $$g$$ = -9.8m/s2 for the purposes of this question.


$$\omega\$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=3:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s.

(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #97).

generalfeedback.text:
The frictional force, $$F_f$$, experienced preventing the child from slipping outwards can be expressed as:

$$F_f=\mu .R=\mu .M.g$$

Where $$\mu$$ is the coefficient of friction as given above, $$R$$ is the reaction force between her shoes and the platform, $$M$$ is the child's mass, and $$g$$ is the gravitational constant, as given above.


The centripetal force, $$F_c$$, experienced by the child can be expressed as:

$$F_c=M.a_c=M.r.\omega ^2$$

Where $$r$$ is the distance between the child and the centre of the merry-go-round, and $$a_c$$ is the centripetal acceleration.


At maximum velocity whilst the child is not slipping outwards, these two forces will be balanced. Therefore, equating and simplifying these two expressions gives:

$$\mu .g=r.\omega ^2$$

Therefore:

$$\omega =\sqrt{\frac{\mu .g}{r}}=3$$ rad/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from 'http://minerva.union.edu/labrakes/Phy110_E3_Solution_F11.pdf'
